Award.AwardTitle: MRI Consortium: Development of a Damping Wiggler Beamline for X-Ray Footprinting at NSLS II
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will fund the development of an X-ray synchrotron footprinting beamline located at the National Synchrotron Light Source-II (NSLS-II) at Brookhaven National Laboratory. X-ray synchrotron footprinting (XFP) is a rapidly growing technique that employs intense, ionizing white X-ray light from a synchrotron source to produce solvent-derived hydroxyl radicals that readily cleave the phosphodiester backbone of nucleic acids and covalently modify amino acid side chains in proteins. The microsecond timescales for this chemistry make XFP ideal for probing macromolecular structural dynamics, such as assembly of multi-protein complexes, protein folding process, or changes in protein structure upon ligand binding. Scientific demand for evaluation of increasingly complex physiological systems has exceeded the technical capabilities of the existing X28C XFP beamline facility at NSLS, which will also be affected by the planned replacement of NSLS with NSLS-II by 2015. The new NSLS-II XFP "wiggler" beamline will replace the existing facility and also provide significantly greater white-beam X-ray flux densities for the substantially increased signal to noise required to drive novel and challenging footprinting experiments unattainable using existing technology. These include microsecond time-resolved studies of the dynamics of water in its interaction with macromolecules, characterization of large megaDalton complexes in solution, membrane protein structural analysis, and in vivo studies of macromolecular structure and dynamics.

This program will enhance facilities available to the international user community, while using advanced NSLS-II technologies to drive structural biology studies that are not currently feasible.The existing XFP program serves over forty well-funded established investigators, most of whom have numerous postdoctoral trainees and graduate students who will likely utilize the method in their future careers. Developments in synchrotron XFP technologies coupled to aggressive outreach and dissemination programs have influenced non-synchrotron footprinting and structural mass spectrometry programs that are rapidly expanding across the United States, including commercial application of the technology in biotechnology development, thus reflecting the expanding reach and broad utility of the technique. The NSLS-II XFP beamline facility will represent a unique international resource for x-ray synchrotron footprinting.

POR.DRECONTENT:
X-ray synchrotron footprinting is a rapidly growing technology ideal for the analysis of solution-state structure and dynamics of macromolecules. This technology employs the very intense broadband x-ray beams produced by synchrotron radiation to generate hydroxyl radicals in solution; this occurs on the microsecond timescale appropriate for probing macromolecular dynamics while minimizing sample perturbation. This technique enables the study of these molecules in near-physiological to in vivo conditions, and is highly complementary to the more traditional structural biology techniques of macromolecular crystallography and small angle solution scattering. For many years, synchrotron-based footprinting studies at the National Synchrotron Light Source (NSLS) beamline X28C provided unique insights and approaches for examining fundamental biological mechanisms of folding, ligand binding, catalysis, splicing, transcription, translation, and macromolecular assembly. In 2014, the NSLS was replaced by the NSLS-II, thus the only instrument dedicated to x-ray footprinting was decommissioned. This provided both the necessity to create a new instrument and the opportunity to advance the technology to the next level.

As demand for structural evaluation of more complex physiological systems increases, a major barrier to providing high signal to noise data is maximizing flux density of the x-ray beam. With the support of the National Science Foundation and in partnership with the NSLS-II, we have successfully developed a new instrument for x-ray footprinting at NSLS-II, including design, construction and commissioning of the beamline and experimental endstations. The beamline is designed to provide unmatched flux density to the sample, enabling the study of complex biological systems containing significant hydroxyl radical scavengers, and also enable shorter exposure times to improve the data quality and move the potential time resolution for dynamic studies into the sub-millisecond regime. The beamline is on target to meet these key performance goals as the new NSLS-II facility does the same.

The XFP beamline at NSLS-II is now the premier instrument for performing x-ray footprinting studies in the world. The unique capabilities of the instrument are now available to researchers for investigations of novel and challenging systems unattainable using previous technology. In the first few months of operation, researchers from around the world have initiated studies of virus assembly and infection, conformations of biosensors on nanoscale substrates, time-resolved studies of cellular signaling pathways, footprinting studies in live cells, and a variety of other projects. More than 20 different users have received training at the beamline at this initial stage, more than half of whom were students and postdoctoral scholars. Calls for proposals for use of the instrument are now regularly posted, and demand for the instrument is growing rapidly.
